questions.question: What is the molecular size of propyne and propylene?
Which material has the highest C3H4 uptake at 3000 ppm and what is the value?
questions.answer: SIFSIX-3-Ni has the highest C3H4 uptake at 3000 ppm with a value of 2.65 mmol g−1.

questions.question: What is the selectivity of SIFSIX-3-Ni over C3H6 at 298 K?
questions.answer: The selectivity of SIFSIX-3-Ni over C3H6 at 298 K is greater than 250.

questions.question: How does the C3H4 uptake capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni compare to ELM-12 at approximately 700 ppm?
questions.answer: The C3H4 uptake capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni at approximately 700 ppm is significantly higher at 2.0 mmol g−1, far surpassing ELM-12's capacity of about 0.19 mmol g−1.

questions.question: What role do the anion pillars play in the adsorption process of ultramicroporous materials?
questions.answer: The anion pillars in ultramicroporous materials help in precisely tuning the pore space and geometric disposition for the best match of the C3H4 size/shape, enabling selective C3H4 trap and adsorption.

questions.question: Is the adsorption behavior of C3H4 and C3H6 on SIFSIX-3-Ni identical across the temperature range of 298–313 K?
questions.answer: True. The saturated C3H4 uptake and the profile of the adsorption isotherms on SIFSIX-3-Ni are almost identical in the temperature range of 298–313 K.

questions.question: Does the change in metal node from Ni to Zn in pyrazine-based ultramicroporous materials increase the C3H4 uptake capacity at 3000 ppm?
questions.answer: False. Changing the metal node from Ni to Zn decreases the C3H4 uptake capacity from 2.65 mmol g−1 on SIFSIX-3-Ni to 1.82 mmol g−1 on SIFSIX-3-Zn at 3000 ppm.

questions.question: What is the effect of temperature on the C3H4 adsorption isotherms on SIFSIX-3-Ni?
questions.answer: The saturated C3H4 uptake and the profile of the adsorption isotherms on SIFSIX-3-Ni are almost identical across the temperature range of 298–313 K, indicating strong interactions between the C3H4 molecule and SIFSIX-3-Ni.

questions.question: What is the significance of the pore structure in SIFSIX-3-Ni for C3H4 capture?
questions.answer: The pore structure of SIFSIX-3-Ni, with its unique advantage for trace C3H4 capture, is due to its ability to precisely match the shape and interacting sites of the C3H4 molecule, enabling extremely high C3H4 uptake under ultralow concentration.

questions.question: Can SIFSIX-3-Ni and NbOFFIVE-1-Ni achieve polymer-grade C3H6 by removing C3H4 to below 5 ppm?
questions.answer: True. The breakthrough experiments confirm that SIFSIX-3-Ni and NbOFFIVE-1-Ni can efficiently remove C3H4 from C3H6, potentially achieving polymer-grade C3H6 by reducing C3H4 content to below 5 ppm.

questions.question: Is the adsorption of C3H4 on SIFSIX-3-Ni reversible at 393 K?
questions.answer: True. The adsorption of C3H4 on SIFSIX-3-Ni is reversible at 393 K, as indicated by the hysteresis in the C3H4 adsorption.

questions.question: What is the role of the square grid structure in the pyrazine-based ultramicroporous material for C3H4 capture?
questions.answer: The square grid structure of the pyrazine-based ultramicroporous material plays a crucial role in C3H4 capture by allowing the pore shape and functional site disposition to be varied to match the shape and interacting sites of the C3H4 molecule, making it an effective single-molecule trap.

questions.question: Does the presence of a C=C group and acidic H atoms in both C3H4 and C2H2 result in similar adsorption behaviors on SIFSIX-3-Ni?
questions.answer: False. Despite both C3H4 and C2H2 having a C=C group and acidic H atoms, their adsorption behaviors on SIFSIX-3-Ni are completely different, with C3H4 showing significantly higher uptake.

questions.question: What is the impact of the anion pillar substitution from SiF6 2− to NbOF5 2− on the pore aperture and C3H6 diffusion?
questions.answer: The substitution of the anion pillar from SiF6 2− to NbOF5 2− results in a longer NbF bond length, leading to a reduction of the maximal pore aperture and generating obvious diffusion resistance for C3H6.

questions.question: Is the adsorption capacity of C3H4 on SIFSIX-3-Ni at 3000 ppm higher than on SIFSIX-3-Zn at the same condition?
questions.answer: True. The adsorption capacity of C3H4 at 3000 ppm on SIFSIX-3-Ni is higher (2.65 mmol g−1) compared to SIFSIX-3-Zn (1.82 mmol g−1) at the same condition.

questions.question: What is the effect of temperature on the C3H4 adsorption capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni?
questions.answer: The saturated C3H4 uptake and the profile of the adsorption isotherms on SIFSIX-3-Ni are almost identical across the temperature range of 298–313 K, indicating that temperature has minimal effect on its C3H4 adsorption capacity within this range.

questions.question: How does the C3H4 uptake capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni at 3000 ppm compare to its capacity at 1.0 bar?
questions.answer: The C3H4 uptake capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni at 3000 ppm is 2.65 mmol g−1, and it increases to 2.98 mmol g−1 at 1.0 bar, indicating a higher uptake capacity at higher pressure.

questions.question: Does the C3H4 adsorption capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni surpass that of ELM-12 at approximately 700 ppm?
questions.answer: True. The C3H4 adsorption capacity of SIFSIX-3-Ni at approximately 700 ppm (2.0 mmol g−1) far surpasses that of ELM-12 (about 0.19 mmol g−1).

questions.question: What is the significance of the pore cavity size and functional sites disposition in the design of single-molecule gas traps?
questions.answer: The significance of the pore cavity size and functional sites disposition in the design of single-molecule gas traps lies in their ability to precisely match the structure and shape of the guest molecule, enabling strong interactions and high adsorption energy for efficient gas capture.

questions.question: Is the adsorption of C3H4 on SIFSIX-3-Ni reversible?
questions.answer: True. The adsorption of C3H4 on SIFSIX-3-Ni is reversible, as indicated by the hysteresis in the C3H4 adsorption at 393 K.
